text:
The above two pretty much said it all:

_Favorite_
• Do make an in-depth brief, explaining everything; 
• Let the writers own their work (doing something exactly like the client said won't ever work. It's no different than micromanaging from your boss);
• Be accessible (my communication with clients will highly determine how much I'll be keen on later work. In some current projects I don't even charge for the editing, or smaller tasks, as it's just enjoyable to work with them)
• Know what you want - Figure out the strategy, ask your writer for feedback and what they think, and once everything is decided then you send out the brief.
_Least favorite:_
• Don't get mad at them if they don't it. Often times the best work with a freelancer starts with the second or third project. Eventually they'll get what it's all about.

elements.text: The above two pretty much said it all:
Favorite
Do make an in-depth brief, explaining everything;
Let the writers own their work (doing something exactly like the client said won't ever work. It's no different than micromanaging from your boss);

Be accessible (my communication with clients will highly determine how much I'll be keen on later work. In some current projects I don't even charge for the editing, or smaller tasks, as it's just enjoyable to work with them)
Know what you want - Figure out the strategy, ask your writer for feedback and what they think, and once everything is decided then you send out the brief.
Least favorite:
Don't get mad at them if they don't it. Often times the best work with a freelancer starts with the second or third project. Eventually they'll get what it's all about.

text:
*My Favorite Clients…*
• Hold themselves (and me) accountable when it comes to timelines and deliverables 
• Know what they want, but also trust me to guide them to the right answer
• Provide constructive feedback and explain why they like/don’t like something
• Bonus: Tech-savvy, know their way around collaborative tools
*My Least Favorite Clients…*
• Provide feedback in chunks spread out over time or they get approval from colleagues/managers _after_ giving me their own feedback (so I have to go back and make changes multiple times)
• Aren’t aligned internally on strategy, so I get conflicting signals
• Act like they’re my only client or my full-time employer (e.g. calls/messages me constantly)
• Go outside the agreed upon scope of work

text:
I need some advice on how to best write scientific, research-led articles.

I struggle with writers who give advice that you should first prepare an outline that contains initial ideas, then try to find research to back up your point of view.

It doesn't make sense since the research of a topic (or the question you want to answer) would give you insights which would then roughly help you build what the outcome/outline of the article is, instead of trying to find the science to back up the ideas.

Having said that, when I do all my research up front, by the time I sit down to write an outline, I find that never have enough to make an interesting point of view. So I end up going back and forth.

Please do share what I might be missing!

elements.text:
I need some advice on how to best write scientific, research-led articles.

I struggle with writers who give advice that you should first prepare an outline that contains initial ideas, then try to find research to back up your point of view.

It doesn't make sense since the research of a topic (or the question you want to answer) would give you insights which would then roughly help you build what the outcome/outline of the article is, instead of trying to find the science to back up the ideas.

Having said that, when I do all my research up front, by the time I sit down to write an outline, I find that never have enough to make an interesting point of view. So I end up going back and forth.

Please do share what I might be missing!

text: Good research-led articles I’ve seen are either about an industry (e.g. state of X in Y industry) or an experiment we (as a company) wish we could run but don’t have time/resources to run (e.g. we tried X for three months and here are the results).

elements.text: Good research-led articles I’ve seen are either about an industry (e.g. state of X in Y industry) or an experiment we (as a company) wish we could run but don’t have time/resources to run (e.g. we tried X for three months and here are the results).

text: This is a good question! I've always approached scientific writing with the scientific method framework, which means I start with a hypothesis, whether it's my own or a client's. Research articles, though they should be free of bias and elevate facts above opinion still start with a theory. An outline is a great way to explain the hypothesis and can act as a guide to the types of research you develop. So, in this case, I view the outline as more of way to organize thoughts and help me track my research, rather than an outline to help support an argument. BUT you're right in saying that the research may prove your original hypothesis false, and that's ok. A writer just has to be committed to the truth, put ego aside, and adjust the paper accordingly.

elements.text: This is a good question! I've always approached scientific writing with the scientific method framework, which means I start with a hypothesis, whether it's my own or a client's. Research articles, though they should be free of bias and elevate facts above opinion still start with a theory. An outline is a great way to explain the hypothesis and can act as a guide to the types of research you develop. So, in this case, I view the outline as more of way to organize thoughts and help me track my research, rather than an outline to help support an argument. BUT you're right in saying that the research may prove your original hypothesis false, and that's ok. A writer just has to be committed to the truth, put ego aside, and adjust the paper accordingly.

text:
The “Writing then research” methodology often isn’t  very “scientific”. If you want to be scientific: formulate hypotheses, get data then try to prove your hypotheses wrong. (if you go look for data to confirm your ideas you have more risk of confirmation bias). Then you explain it all.

But if it’s more you want to use science to reinforce your ideas and it’s more content than actual research, then it’s a bit different.

First of all, there is no right approach, there’s only the one that works for you.

About the “Writing then research” approach: generally implies you’re writing about something you’re already familiar with. Also often implies that you have a reading + taking notes habit so that when you actually start writing you’re more “assembling” than creating from scratch, like, you have pre-thought ideas. Then you go back to research when some points need data to be strengthened.

If you’re discovering the topic though, you obviously can’t do that. You kinda have to start with research (careful about your sources). Making it interesting in that case I think is then more a question about who’s gonna read your article and making it useful for them. It’s pretty unlikely you’ll have an earth-shattering point of view on a topic you’re discovering so y’know^^. Although you can go interview experts about it.

K dunno if all this makes much sense or if it’s useful but htere you go :joy:

text: Hypothesis-led is probably what you'd have to do when the client is a business with a product to "push", but otherwise "question-led" would be an alternative. It would also hand you your outline on a silver platter: introducing the question / conundrum; research in favor, research against, weighed opinion, next questions to answer and/or what does this tell you - how can you put this to work for you.

elements.text: Hypothesis-led is probably what you'd have to do when the client is a business with a product to "push", but otherwise "question-led" would be an alternative. It would also hand you your outline on a silver platter: introducing the question / conundrum; research in favor, research against, weighed opinion, next questions to answer and/or what does this tell you - how can you put this to work for you.

text:
I'm gonna say quantity over quality. And I'd say that 1-3 posts per week is quantity.

And let's be honest, some posts deserve a month of research & interviews, others don't.

Quantity helps you practice, creates the reading habit (as mentioned above) & gets your team in gear. It also forces you to try new things

Posted recently abt this on LI <https://www.linkedin.com/posts/joshspilker_contentstrategy-contentmarketing-activity-6679231781226598400-Woi2>

attachments.title: Josh Spilker posted on LinkedIn
attachments.text: One of the reasons I&#39;m big on quantity over quality: It helps you produce and then fail You&#39;re refining your purposes and processes as much as serving...

text: What's the best practice when updating an old blog post? Should you update the publish date or keep the original publish date and make a note in the body of the blog when and why you updated the piece? I'm not sure if changing the publish date affects the SEO.

elements.text: What's the best practice when updating an old blog post? Should you update the publish date or keep the original publish date and make a note in the body of the blog when and why you updated the piece? I'm not sure if changing the publish date affects the SEO.

text: The CMS should automatically update the date the post was updated. There's no need to state in the body the post was updated, unless it's time sensitive and updates to the content are crucial (let's say a news coverage). :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: The CMS should automatically update the date the post was updated. There's no need to state in the body the post was updated, unless it's time sensitive and updates to the content are crucial (let's say a news coverage).

text: For us, when the updates are substantial... Like new content, new examples, more current data, and the introduction and other parts of the content speak to a new context, we hit update and also update the publish date ... I've never read anything that says Google notices this and cares, but for search results the date can show it's more recent than other competing results which may matter to users

elements.text: For us, when the updates are substantial... Like new content, new examples, more current data, and the introduction and other parts of the content speak to a new context, we hit update and also update the publish date ... I've never read anything that says Google notices this and cares, but for search results the date can show it's more recent than other competing results which may matter to users

text: Thanks, <@UV5TB6FQW>. That makes perfect sense. I was worried that while promoting the updated post, our customers would wonder, why are you bringing up this post from a year ago, when they saw the publish date. Just wanted to make it clear why it was relevant again.

text:
Google can and does see the publish and updated dates. But they seem to prioritize one over the other.

That said, I've run tests on sites with 100k+ visitors per month and you can literally see the DAY we went into old posts (2017 to 2018) and updated the publish date here:

elements.text:
Google can and does see the publish and updated dates. But they seem to prioritize one over the other.

That said, I've run tests on sites with 100k+ visitors per month and you can literally see the DAY we went into old posts (2017 to 2018) and updated the publish date here:

text: Now, we didn't update any of the content here because we wanted to isolate the change.

elements.text: Now, we didn't update any of the content here because we wanted to isolate the change.

text: And you can see, it worked.

elements.text: And you can see, it worked.

text: Do I recommend people do this in a spammy way? Ew. No. Don't do that.

elements.text: Do I recommend people do this in a spammy way? Ew. No. Don't do that.

text: But from an SEO perspective, _right now_, should you update the publish date when you update older posts (6-12 months old)? Absolutely.

right now

text:
A few thoughts:
• Updating existing content affects SEO
• Updating the last modified date (or published date) affects SEO as well, at the very least because often the date is shown in your snippet in Google and most people prefer newer content  over older content.
• That said, Google’s pretty good at figuring out whether old content has _really_ been updated or not, because they know what your old content looked like.
I always update the last modified date after updating.

That said, Google’s pretty good at figuring out whether old content has
really
been updated or not, because they know what your old content looked like.
I always update the last modified date after updating.

text:
Technically a chrome extension is its own product, but as it probably is 'just' a way to make using your product on the web easier, it is functionally a feature of your product.

Yes, it is integrated with your product, but the terms 'integrate' and 'integration' are mostly used for integrations with other products. Your own (like Outlook and Word from MS) or from someone else, like Slack integrates with Google Drive and many others.

text: Hi everyone! I'm new in town, so I apologize if this question has been asked before but it's one I've been grappling with for a while. Our blog has started to feel a bit like a dumping ground for things like funding announcements, client marketing blogs, prospect marketing blogs, "brand refresh" announcements, and so on. All have different audiences, and it muddies the water when I want to keep the blog clear for posts that support an actual content marketing strategy for prospects. Has anyone else felt this way before and do you have good solutions for it? I want to give other teams an outlet for publishing on their efforts, but I'm not sure what to suggest (we've tried a separate Medium page and it has somewhat flopped).

elements.text: Hi everyone! I'm new in town, so I apologize if this question has been asked before but it's one I've been grappling with for a while. Our blog has started to feel a bit like a dumping ground for things like funding announcements, client marketing blogs, prospect marketing blogs, "brand refresh" announcements, and so on. All have different audiences, and it muddies the water when I want to keep the blog clear for posts that support an actual content marketing strategy for prospects. Has anyone else felt this way before and do you have good solutions for it? I want to give other teams an outlet for publishing on their efforts, but I'm not sure what to suggest (we've tried a separate Medium page and it has somewhat flopped).

text: Another approach here is to have a dedicated "company news blog". This is what HubSpot does.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: Another approach here is to have a dedicated "company news blog". This is what HubSpot does.

text:
HubSpot also uses Medium for these types of posts. I would describe the strategy like this:
1. product blogs -- primarily for search
2. <https://medium.com/@HubSpot|Medium> -- company news with a softer angle that is of interest to the broader tech/startup world (Medium's primary audience)
3. <https://www.hubspot.com/company-news|Company news blog> -- press releases, awards, content that's relevant to investors and big partners, it's the official record

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz
